head.supplied: 12/10/89. ¶ ¶ Altho' Mr French has not yet arrived, dear Prof. Tate, I write in advance of the coming collection a few lines in sparemoments of the Saturday-evening. ¶ ¶ Blyxa is derived from ¶ Βλυ...

div.p: Barr Smith Library, University of Adelaide, SA.
Altho' Mr French has not yet arrived, dear Prof. Tate, I write in advance of the coming collection a few lines in sparemoments of the Saturday-evening.
Blyxa is derived from Βλυξϖ, gushing because this weed gushes forth in the water.

Schedonorus is from σχεδον near οροσ top, because the arista of the original species emanates from near the summit of the supporting floral bract.
Tate had evidently asked M's help with the explanations of specific and generic names given in the 'Index to orders and genera' in Tate (1890), pp. 286-300. M's explanations were used for Blyxa , Schedonorus
and the specific epithet pseudevax, although the derivation of
Evax
was not included.

Evax is the name of an Arabian King, who lived at the commencement of the christian era, and wrote on medical plants. The Chthonocephalus Pseudevax has its name from the resemblance to some species of Evax, that genus comprising several specific forms in the countries at the mediterranean Sea among Composites.
I am glad, you have your Flora ready, so that it can be used already this season.

I may not have admitted in the Census
B89.12.03. all species from S.A., as some would best be subjected to a critical further close comparison. In the same manner I have left plants unnoticed from all the other colonies, because I had not yet leisure enough, to examine all the new species or the plants from new localities carefully. It is better that the Census should remain somewhat incomplete, than to withdraw again entries subsequently. Supplements must appear anyhow.
No such supplements were published. If divine providence will spare me life yet for a year or two, — I trust, to bring up all arrears in 1890 & 1891.

I gladly will join in the authorship of a report on Mr Tietkens's plants, but it will take still a few weeks to bring the descriptions of all the plants of Sir Will. Macgregor through the press,
B89.13.11. and in Nov. & Dec. will so many duties as extra-work (to the daily heavy routine) devolve on me in connection with the Melbourne meeting of the Australian Assoc.
M was President of the Second Congress of the Australasian Association for the Advancement of Science, to be held in Melbourne in January 1890. Is it needful, that the whole 250 spec. of Tietkens's collection be published at one?
at once? Tate and M listed Tietkens's plants in B90.14.03, read before the Royal Society of SA on 1 April 1890; the paper includes descriptions of several new species, pp. 107-9. The doubtful ones could surely be left out, as each of them might require hours of conscientious research, and then the result might not be conclusive, if either flowers or fruits are wanting

div.p: I have not yet written any portion of the presidential adress. The Sundays & Holidays, when alone I could collect my thoughts for such a purpose, have been occupied with other urgent studies all through the year.

Mr French will not return before Tuesday. I will see to the plants, so soon as they come
Charles French (1840-1933), Vic Government entomologist, arrived in Adelaide on 3 October 1889 to study economic entomology (South Australian chronicle, 5 October 1889, p. 4). He was evidently to bring M a set of plants from Tate, possibly the plants announced in M to R. Tate, 17 October 1889 (in this edition as 89-10-17b).
